name: Availability
description: The expected reliability of a computer system including software, hardware and networks

components.name: design principles
components.definition: That engineering is effectively implementing designs and these are used consistently across delivery.
components.comments: only 1 criteria is in the tool and no questions

criteria.name: Some design principles are followed by individuals.
Attempts to establish design principles initially at individual team level.
Group-wide architecture and design principles are established and followed in predictable manner.

components.name: availability testing
components.definition: proves that the platform is resilient to component failures thereby maximising availability

criteria.name: Some adhoc availability testing is done but depends on individual effort.
Initial attempts to establish repeatable testing processes for availability. Representative test environments may be used for availability testing.
Group-wide availability testing processes are established and followed. Representative test environments are used consistently for availability testing.

components.name: availability testing and monitoring tools
components.comment: no questions for this, replicates to some extent what is in the monitoring topic

criteria.name: Basic or bespoke tools are used for availability testing and monitoring.

Initial implementation of availability testing and monitoring tools across the team. Tools may include blue-green deployment support in deployment pipelines, "chaos engineering" utilities, network, host, and application monitoring.
Group-wide standards are set for availability testing and monitoring tools. Tools are used in highly predictive manner.

Group-wide standards are set for availability testing and monitoring tools. Tools are used in highly predictive manner that adds value across teams and business units. Tools may include blue-green deployment support in deployment pipelines, "chaos engineering" utilities, network, host, and application monitoring.

components.name: requirements
components.definition: expectations of system availability are clearly established and documented

criteria.name: Availability requirements are collected in adhoc manner and are not quantified.
Initial attempts to establish requirements process for availability. It includes specification of some availability goals by business stakeholders. SLAs and SLOs are starting to be established.
Group-wide requirements process for availability is established and followed. It includes specification of quantifiable availability goals by business stakeholders. SLAs and SLOs are established.
Operational standards are being established with respect to availability, including documentation and training, to support high availability at network, host, and application levels.
Group-wide operational standards are established, including documentation and training, to support high availability at network, host, and application levels.

components.name: availability monitoring
components.definition: The health of all components in the platform needs to be continuously monitored to know if the required availability level from the perspective of customers is being achieved

criteria.name: Some adhoc availability monitoring is performed but not yet systematic and consistent.
Some availability-related data is collected, but it is not done in consistent manner.
Reactive availability monitoring in place - customers/end-users/interfacing systems notify service owners of availability issue
Initial attempt to define availability metrics to capture during deployment and operation.
Initial attempt to define availability metrics to capture during deployment and operation.
availability data is collected consistent with group standards and is available in group monitoring tools
Availability metrics are compared with SLAs and SLOs.
Availability metrics such as Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are collected consistently. Metrics along the path between systems are collected consistently.
Availability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability.
Availability metrics are collected consistently and improvement goals are set with relation to SLA and SLOs.

components.name: highly available by design
components.definition: is the platform designed in such a way that failures of individual components does not make the entire platform unavailable, and upgrades do not require the platform to be made unavailable

criteria.name: when issues are detected in a component the platform can be switched to use other redundant instances
PR.PT-5: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
application/platform is composed of self healing components: if an instance of a component is detected as unhealthy it is automatically replaced by a new instance with no impact on users

upgrades to components is done in way that has no affect on availability: a subset of users are automatically moved to upgraded components and if anomolies are detected the upgrade is automatically rolled back

questions.definition: How does your team and system define “availability”?
Are you tracking any availability metrics and data?

Are you using any tools or processes to test and monitor availability? Are these integrated with group-wide tooling and metrics? 
a.	Integration with third-parties — e.g., Verizon
b.	Cloud and On-Premise.
Do you have any availability goals derived from business SLAs/SLOs?
What are your SLAs and SLOs with respect to Availability?
What testing processes and environments do you have in place? Do your test environments topologically mirror production?
Do you regularly test different failure modes with controlled experiments?
What is your system’s ARC Tier, and how do you measure adherence to its requirements?
How does your team come to learn of availability issues?
What tools do you use to investigate availability issues?
What other systems (infrastructure, upstream, downstream or otherwise) affect your system’s availability? (e.g. DNS, networks)
Is the system architecture fully resilient, with redundancy and/or replication and failover at all necessary components (LB, Applications, DB, HSM)
